The document that seems to match the points in the memo is a notice sent to readers of the Alumni Record on Aug. 2, 1960, shortly after Professor Sheils' resignation. It says only that "this office will be unable to supply a Record until a successor is hired." An application was published the same day in The Crimson, a student-run paper, for an "editorial assistant" and for a "senior editorial assistant."

Twenty-one-year-old John Donovan, an economics major, responded to the advertisement that The Crimson ran on Aug. 9, 1960. He was initially declined but was then hired as an "editorial assistant" in the Alumni Record office at 727 Boylston St. After graduation, he worked for graduate student publications at Harvard and subsequently for small trade magazines in New York and Chicago. He is now director of marketing communications at GCA Associates, a market research firm in Cambridge.

Ms. Hazeltine applied to join the Record in September 1961 and was selected a month later, during her senior year.

"It was one of the last reporting jobs at the Record," she said. When she arrived, she believed "the office was still filled with what had remained of the Underhill era." She shared a desk with Mr. Donovan and worked as a "one-man staff," handling everything from correspondence to the Office of the University Secretary to correspondence with about 25,000 alums. The Alumni Record was a three-column, single-column, black-and-white paper. The previous year it was printed 1,800 times a year and included a one-page brochure for alumni.

Professor Sheils was already gone.

"He'd made an enemy and I was the first person he told," Ms. Hazeltine said of Mr. Havens, the professor who hired her to the Record. "I worked for John Havens," she said.

Mr. Havens was assigned to work on developing and writing speeches for the University administrators and giving notes on developing form letters. When the Alumni Record opened again in 1962, Ms. Hazeltine was hired as an "office manager."

How did they become alumni relations professionals?

"I was an editor and Ms. Hazeltine was my receptionist," Mr. Donovan said. He was one of a handful of "editorial assistants" who did manual labor and menial jobs, "like filling envelopes." Ms. Hazeltine helped him build up an address list. "I'd take over her lunch-time table, from 'The Crimson' to 'The Record,' " he said.

Mr. Donovan was "astonished" that Ms. Hazeltine had progressed to the position of office manager. "I thought it was quite remarkable because I was not aware that I had done anything to take them in that direction." She eventually became "executive secretary" and then "director of alumni relations."

"I have no doubt that she was picked for her ingenuity," he said. "I thought it was a dazzling ability that she had."

"Much of my training was on the job," Ms. Hazeltine said. "My company was unique in allowing for the accumulation of experience and then promotion within the company. This would be in contrast to more recently [than 1960] when many of us, having applied to the company, may not be given much opportunity for advancement."

What did they do after their tenure at the Alumni Record?

After he graduated in June 1963, Mr. Donovan worked at McGraw-Hill in New York for one year. He then joined the administration of the Iribarren School of Hotel and Catering Management (whose University of Havana had been wiped out by the Cuban Revolution) and the School of Nursing at Sanitation Medical Center (whose major salesperson quit over a head count and fled to Cuba).

After leaving Iribarren and Sanitation in 1969, Mr. Donovan joined the New York City tax-free fund company William Mercer. He is now director of marketing communications at GCA Associates, a market research firm in Cambridge. In 1996 he left his company to write a book about student politics at Harvard.

Ms. Hazeltine received a master's in library science in 1973 and a law degree in 1980. She practiced law in New York before becoming a university liaison officer at the U.S. House of Representatives Library. After moving to Washington in 1982, she worked for several firms as an information consultant before moving to Harvard in 1986. She retired from Harvard in 2005 but then became an advisory board member of CIBER, Harvard's entrepreneurship and innovation initiative.

How do they see their professions today?

"There are now so many universities hiring people, but I see it as a small pool," Mr. Donovan said. "Most people at Harvard are doing it because they think they are doing it for Harvard and for the students, not because they want to get rich. It is the kind of group where it is possible to have a little psychic income."

title: Chloroplast
context: Cryptophytes, or cryptomonads are a group of algae that contain a red-algal derived chloroplast. Cryptophyte chloroplasts contain a nucleomorph that superficially resembles that of the chlorarachniophytes. Cryptophyte chloroplasts have four membranes, the outermost of which is continuous with the rough endoplasmic reticulum. They synthesize ordinary starch, which is stored in granules found in the periplastid space—outside the original double membrane, in the place that corresponds to the red alga's cytoplasm. Inside cryptophyte chloroplasts is a pyrenoid and thylakoids in stacks of two.

title: Economic inequality
context: 2013 Economics Nobel prize winner Robert J. Shiller said that rising inequality in the United States and elsewhere is the most important problem. Increasing inequality harms economic growth. High and persistent unemployment, in which inequality increases, has a negative effect on subsequent long-run economic growth. Unemployment can harm growth not only because it is a waste of resources, but also because it generates redistributive pressures and subsequent distortions, drives people to poverty, constrains liquidity limiting labor mobility, and erodes self-esteem promoting social dislocation, unrest and conflict. Policies aiming at controlling unemployment and in particular at reducing its inequality-associated effects support economic growth.

Persistent unemployment has what effect on long-term economic growth?
What's one factor in eroding self-esteem?
Policies which reduce the inequality associated effects of unemployment support what type of growth?

completions:
1. Robert J. Shiller, a 2013 Economics Nobel prize winner, identified rising inequality in the United States and elsewhere as the most important problem.
2. Rising inequality has negative effects on economic growth.
3. High and persistent unemployment, which leads to inequality, also harms economic growth.
4. High and persistent unemployment can generate redistributive pressures, subsequent distortions, push people to poverty, limit liquidity and labor mobility, and erode self-esteem, promoting social dislocation, unrest, and conflict.
5. Policies aiming to control unemployment and reduce its inequality-associated effects support economic growth.

Implications:
1. Addressing rising inequality should be a priority to ensure economic growth.
2. Addressing high and persistent unemployment and its associated effects is essential for sustaining economic growth.
3. Policies targeting unemployment and reducing its inequality effects can promote economic growth and stability.

The passage discusses the issue of economic inequality and its impact on economic growth, unemployment, and overall societal well-being. It highlights the findings of Robert J. Shiller, the 2013 Economics Nobel prize winner, who considers economic inequality as the most significant problem in today's world. The text states that increasing inequality negatively impacts economic growth, and that unemployment, which often causes inequality, has a detrimental effect on long-term economic growth. The passage highlights various reasons why unemployment can harm economic growth, including the waste of resources, pressure on redistribution, and its impact on poverty, liquidity, self-esteem, and social unrest. Finally, it emphasizes that policies that aim to control unemployment and reduce its inequality-associated effects can support economic growth.

Implications:
1. Economic inequality is a significant issue that, if not addressed, can severely affect economic growth.
2. Increasing inequality can have a negative impact on economic growth.
3. Unemployment, often caused by inequality, can harm long-term economic growth.
4. Unemployment has a multifaceted negative impact on the economy, including waste of resources, redistributive pressure, and the resulting distortions.
5. Unemployment can contribute to poverty, limit liquidity, and erode self-esteem, leading to social dislocation and unrest.
6. Policies aimed at controlling unemployment and reducing its inequality-associated effects can support economic growth.

When people don't have any money, they can't buy food and things they need. That makes it hard for the country to grow and get better. To fix this, we need to make sure everyone has enough money and help them get jobs.

2. High and persistent unemployment contributes to inequality and hampers economic growth.

4. Policies to control unemployment and address the inequality-associated effects can support economic growth.
5. Income distribution should be addressed to ensure that everyone has a chance to succeed and contribute to economic growth.

prompt:
Let's read the following passage, think step by step, and then produce a list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content. We should first generate a "Thought Process" and then "Implications"

Passage:
Economic inequality
2013 Economics Nobel prize winner Robert J. Shiller said that rising inequality in the United States and elsewhere is the most important problem. Increasing inequality harms economic growth. High and persistent unemployment, in which inequality increases, has a negative effect on subsequent long-run economic growth. Unemployment can harm growth not only because it is a waste of resources, but also because it generates redistributive pressures and subsequent distortions, drives people to poverty, constrains liquidity limiting labor mobility, and erodes self-esteem promoting social dislocation, unrest and conflict. Policies aiming at controlling unemployment and in particular at reducing its inequality-associated effects support economic growth.

title: Genghis Khan
context: In 1226, immediately after returning from the west, Genghis Khan began a retaliatory attack on the Tanguts. His armies quickly took Heisui, Ganzhou, and Suzhou (not the Suzhou in Jiangsu province), and in the autumn he took Xiliang-fu[disambiguation needed]. One of the Tangut generals challenged the Mongols to a battle near Helan Mountains but was defeated. In November, Genghis laid siege to the Tangut city Lingzhou and crossed the Yellow River, defeating the Tangut relief army. According to legend, it was here that Genghis Khan reportedly saw a line of five stars arranged in the sky and interpreted it as an omen of his victory.

title: Harvard University
context: Harvard's 2,400 professors, lecturers, and instructors instruct 7,200 undergraduates and 14,000 graduate students. The school color is crimson, which is also the name of the Harvard sports teams and the daily newspaper, The Harvard Crimson. The color was unofficially adopted (in preference to magenta) by an 1875 vote of the student body, although the association with some form of red can be traced back to 1858, when Charles William Eliot, a young graduate student who would later become Harvard's 21st and longest-serving president (1869–1909), bought red bandanas for his crew so they could more easily be distinguished by spectators at a regatta.

title: Apollo program
context: After an unmanned LM test flight AS-206, a crew would fly the first Block II CSM and LM in a dual mission known as AS-207/208, or AS-278 (each spacecraft would be launched on a separate Saturn IB.) The Block II crew positions were titled Commander (CDR) Command Module Pilot (CMP) and Lunar Module Pilot (LMP). The astronauts would begin wearing a new Apollo spacesuit, designed to accommodate lunar extravehicular activity (EVA). The traditional visor helmet was replaced with a clear "fishbowl" type for greater visibility, and the lunar surface EVA suit would include a water-cooled undergarment.

Can you tell me about some of the interactions between the Mongols and the Han Chinese during the Yuan dynasty?

The interactions between the Mongols and the Han Chinese during the Yuan dynasty were quite complex, as both groups had to adapt to the other's culture and way of life in order to maintain stability and control in the empire. Here are some examples:

1. The Mongols employed Han Chinese officials and scholars to serve in various roles in the government, military, and administration of the empire. They respected the Han Chinese for their knowledge and expertise in various fields, and recognized their importance in ruling over such a vast and diverse empire.

2. The Han Chinese and Mongols also interacted in the areas of trade and commerce. The Mongols opened up new trade routes and established a network of cities and towns that became important centers of trade and cultural exchange between China and the rest of the world.

3. Han Chinese artisans and craftsmen were also employed by the Mongols to create products for the imperial court, as well as for the general population. The Mongols were particularly interested in Chinese art, literature, and philosophy, and often commissioned Han Chinese scholars to write works for them.

4. Despite their cultural differences, the Mongols and Han Chinese often found common ground in their desire to maintain stability and order in the empire. The Mongols were able to tap into the Han Chinese's vast knowledge and experience in governance, while the Han Chinese were able to learn from the Mongols' military and administrative skills.

5. However, there were also tensions between the Mongols and Han Chinese, particularly in the early years of the dynasty. Some Han Chinese resented the Mongol rule, while others were wary of being used as pawns in the Mongols' larger political strategy. There were also clashes between the Mongol elite and the Han Chinese commoners, as well as between different groups of Han Chinese, over questions of power and privilege.

In sum, the interactions between the Mongols and Han Chinese during the Yuan dynasty were characterized by a complex mix of cultural exchange, mutual respect, and tension. While there were many challenges, the dynasty was ultimately able to maintain stability and order through the use of foreign administrators and the adaptability of both groups.

Thought Process:

title: Martin Luther
context: The theologians, including Zwingli, Melanchthon, Martin Bucer, and Johannes Oecolampadius, differed on the significance of the words spoken by Jesus at the Last Supper: "This is my body which is for you" and "This cup is the new covenant in my blood" (1 Corinthians 11:23–26). Luther insisted on the Real Presence of the body and blood of Christ in the consecrated bread and wine, which he called the sacramental union, while his opponents believed God to be only spiritually or symbolically present. Zwingli, for example, denied Jesus' ability to be in more than one place at a time but Luther stressed the omnipresence of his human nature. According to transcripts, the debate sometimes became confrontational. Citing Jesus' words "The flesh profiteth nothing" (John 6.63), Zwingli said, "This passage breaks your neck". "Don't be too proud," Luther retorted, "German necks don't break that easily. This is Hesse, not Switzerland." On his table Luther wrote the words "Hoc est corpus meum" ("This is my body") in chalk, to continually indicate his firm stance.

Passage:
Examples of plants that produce compounds called cyanogenic glycosides include cherry, cotton, peach, and bamboo. Such compounds form in the plant as a defense mechanism against herbivory, breaking down in the gut of the animal to reveal hydrogen cyanide, which is toxic to most animals.
The role of cyanogenic glycosides as a primary defense mechanism in plants is unknown. Some hypotheses suggest they are used to prevent the germination of seeds or to kill pathogens. Plants such as the apple (Malus domestica) or the peach (Prunus persica) have an active enzyme called linamarase that converts linamarin (the cyanogenic glycoside) to hydrogen cyanide. The ingestion of linamarin by bees is prevented by the color of the blossom, whereas moth and butterfly larvae feeding on nectar are immune to the toxin. The amygdalin in apple blossoms is broken down by the enzyme emulsin. Amygdalin is therefore not harmful to honey bees, but it may be harmful to moths, butterflies, and other invertebrate pollinators. In fish the metabolites of hydrogen cyanide produced by cyanogenic glycosides may act as bitter taste deterrents.

Thought Process:

2. Discuss the role of cyanogenic glycosides as a defense mechanism against herbivory.

4. Discuss hypotheses about the primary defense mechanism of cyanogenic glycosides in plants.
5. Provide examples of plants like apple and peach that have an active enzyme called linamarase to convert cyanogenic glycosides.
6. Mention how the ingestion of linamarin by bees is prevented due to the color of the blossom.
7. Discuss the immunity of moth and butterfly larvae to the toxin in plants.
8. Explain how the amygdalin in apple blossoms is broken down by the enzyme emulsin.
9. Compare the effects of hydrogen cyanide metabolites on honeybees and invertebrate pollinators.
10. Provide evidence of cyanogenic glycosides in fish as bitter taste deterrents.

Implications:
1. The presence of cyanogenic glycosides as a defense mechanism in plants suggests that these compounds can deter herbivores.
2. The breakdown of cyanogenic glycosides in the animal's gut and release of hydrogen cyanide indicate their toxicity to most animals.
3. Different pollinators, such as bees and invertebrates, have varying susceptibilities to the toxic effects of cyanogenic glycosides.
4. In fish, cyanogenic glycosides may provide an additional defense mechanism, acting as a bitter taste deterrent.
5. The role of cyanogenic glycosides as a primary defense mechanism in plants may not be well understood, but hypotheses suggest they can prevent seed germination and kill pathogens.
6. Apple and peach plants have evolved mechanisms to combat the toxic effects of cyanogenic glycosides, highlighting the importance of these compounds in plant defense strategies.
7. The diversity of cyanogenic glycosides in different plants indicates their potential role in adaptation and evolution to specific environmental conditions.
8. The different outcomes of cyanogenic glycosides in honey bees and invertebrate pollinators suggest that these compounds can have varied effects based on factors such as metabolism and exposure.

title: Steam engine
context: The first commercially successful true engine, in that it could generate power and transmit it to a machine, was the atmospheric engine, invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712. It was an improvement over Savery's steam pump, using a piston as proposed by Papin. Newcomen's engine was relatively inefficient, and in most cases was used for pumping water. It worked by creating a partial vacuum by condensing steam under a piston within a cylinder. It was employed for draining mine workings at depths hitherto impossible, and also for providing a reusable water supply for driving waterwheels at factories sited away from a suitable "head". Water that had passed over the wheel was pumped back up into a storage reservoir above the wheel.

4. The steam engine's success contributed to the growth of the industrial revolution and the modernization of industries.
5. The atmospheric engine paved the way for more efficient and powerful steam engines that would come later in the industrial revolution.

James Watt
James Watt (1763-1819) improved the steam engine using separate condenser, and this tripled the efficiency of Newcomen's engine. His use of a separate condenser to recover waste heat and avoid the high power loss inherent in Newcomen's "blanket" method of cooling with fresh steam was the beginning of the use of high-level regenerative heat recovery in engineering. This pioneering application of thermodynamics at a level yielding financial reward also inspired James Joule's later calculations on the mechanical equivalent of heat. Charles Porter's 1834 Manchester rollers citation is a principal point of Smeaton's 1755 manuscript wherein he claimed Watt's improvement as a copyright infringement upon Smeaton's own 1767 finding that steam can be condensed separately from the water being raised, in order to pump coal out of mines. Smeaton's 1767 condensing-only engine was never equipped to provide sufficient power for driving any auxiliary machinery. Smeaton's design was a radical departure from the earlier 1712 engine of Thomas Newcomen which was a costly project for the manufacturers of the day. That dispute over Watt's technical debt claims was finally settled in 1839, 19 years after Smeaton's death when his heirs sued both Samuel Homfray and the Newcomen Society for miners' histories, with the right to collect for centuries of questionable debt claims. Homfray was a widower and a master clockmaker. He was a new shareholder in the Harmony Coal & Iron Company, located in Merthyr Tydfil.

Treating Future States
One of the first disadvantages of Artificial Intelligence is the amount of time it requires to treat future states. One of the main reasons for this is the exponential increase of the amount of factors that have to be used to solve any problem. In a route choice problem, for example, the possible number of combinations of routes is exponential in the number of nodes in the network. For example, with a network of 10 nodes, there are 9*9*9*9*9*9*9*9*9*9 = 348,678,440,100 possible combinations of route choices. This is even more when you take the order of the choices into account and when intermediate nodes can be bypassed without penalty. Furthermore, in the case of a route choice problem it may be possible to continue indefinitely and the problem may never reach a conclusion. With traditional computing methods, it is very hard to work out solutions to cases such as these, and the AI system will need to decide whether to seek a solution, risk not reaching the correct solution, or sacrifice speed in the search for an optimal solution.

title: Prime number
context: Modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided into two main classes, probabilistic (or "Monte Carlo") and deterministic algorithms. Deterministic algorithms provide a way to tell for sure whether a given number is prime or not. For example, trial division is a deterministic algorithm because, if performed correctly, it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite. Probabilistic algorithms are normally faster, but do not completely prove that a number is prime. These tests rely on testing a given number in a partly random way. For example, a given test might pass all the time if applied to a prime number, but pass only with probability p if applied to a composite number. If we repeat the test n times and pass every time, then the probability that our number is composite is 1/(1-p)n, which decreases exponentially with the number of tests, so we can be as sure as we like (though never perfectly sure) that the number is prime. On the other hand, if the test ever fails, then we know that the number is composite.

Humanism flourished in particular in the powerful city-state of Florence, where a wealthy merchant class generated the wealth that allowed extensive patronage of the arts, and also came to power itself, taking control from the traditional nobility. Humanism became both cultural and intellectual movement.

Banknote
As paper currency became more widespread, countries began to issue coins for the most common denominations. This has varied from country to country, but in practice most coins have denominations of ¼, ½, 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, and 50 of the base unit. An exception to this rule is the United States, which issues a 3-cent piece, a 5-cent piece, and a 25-cent or ¼-dollar coin. Historically, ¼- and ½-pieces were more common, and can be found in British currency in the early 1960s and some other places until recently. These smaller denominations were required to adjust for the fact that currency bills come in only certain sizes, so several small-denomination items could be used rather than large currency bills.

Passage:
Iranian captives in Iraq and Iran should be released, Washington envoy says
U.S. negotiators should tell Iranian and Iraqi officials that the two countries need each other more than they need Syria or Russia or Hezbollah, U.S. special representative Brian Hook said.
Hook made the comments to Fox News on Thursday after Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian and his counterparts in Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates held talks in Doha that touched on Iran.
"In any case, it's in the interest of everybody and particularly the United States to encourage Iran and Iraq to be on the right path," Hook told Fox News.
Hook said he and Amirabdollahian had recently met in the Middle East, and he said the two sides discussed the need to allow former Iranian prisoners to be returned to Iran, and the need to allow the Iraqi state to have access to oil, and the oil revenues, in order to rebuild the country.
"So, the Iranian captives in Iraq and the Iraqi captives in Iran should be released," Hook said. "And they should seek a future in which they bring their military apparatus down and stop the chaos."
Hook said he believed a new round of negotiations that included the Islamic Republic was underway in Vienna, although he would not comment on the topic specifically.
"It's becoming more fruitful by the day," he said.
Hook also touched on the progress that has been made in 12-rounds of Iranian nuclear talks, saying "we're making slow and incremental progress."
"In terms of what we are looking for, we don't want to see Iran have a robust nuclear program," he said. "We want to see Iran commit to the full spectrum of verification steps. We want to see Iran do more things to rebuild confidence in the international community that they aren't pursuing the development of a weapon for their own purposes."
He added that the United States will not agree to talks until Iran comes to the table with a credible and enforceable package.
"You can't address Iran's recent defiant actions toward the United States with further concessions. What we will need to see is in the interests of all concerned parties," Hook said. "We would like to see Iran come back and show that it's willing to get a satisfactory deal with a robust set of commitments that can be fully enforced and fully adhered to."

Thought Process:
1. Iranian captives in Iraq and Iran should be released according to a U.S. envoy.
2. The U.S. special representative, Brian Hook, believes that Iran and Iraq need each other more than they need Syria, Russia, or Hezbollah.
3. Hook suggests that the United States should encourage Iran and Iraq to focus on their mutual interests and avoid pursuing relations with other potentially hostile entities.
4. Hook mentioned recent meetings with Iranian foreign minister, Hossein Amirabdollahian, and discussed the need for release of prisoners, allowing oil access and reconstruction in Iraq.
5. Hook believes that Iran and Iraq should reduce their military presence and stop contributing to chaos.
6. Hook reported that negotiations involving Iran are taking place in Vienna, although he did not discuss the specifics.
7. Hook mentioned that progress has been made in nuclear talks and the United States is seeking a comprehensive and enforceable agreement.
8. The United States will not engage in further talks unless Iran shows credible and enforceable commitments.

Implications:
1. Releasing Iranian captives in Iraq and Iran is considered important for the United States.
2. The U.S. envoy advocates for Iran and Iraq to prioritize their mutual interests over relationships with other hostile entities.
3. Iran and Iraq should reduce their military presence and avoid contributing to chaos.
4. Nuclear talks with Iran are progressing, and the United States is seeking a comprehensive and enforceable agreement.
5. The United States will not engage in further talks unless Iran shows credible and enforceable commitments.

Thought Process:

title: Chloroplast
context: Lepidodinium viride and its close relatives are dinophytes that lost their original peridinin chloroplast and replaced it with a green algal derived chloroplast (more specifically, a prasinophyte). Lepidodinium is the only dinophyte that has a chloroplast that's not from the rhodoplast lineage. The chloroplast is surrounded by two membranes and has no nucleomorph—all the nucleomorph genes have been transferred to the dinophyte nucleus. The endosymbiotic event that led to this chloroplast was serial secondary endosymbiosis rather than tertiary endosymbiosis—the endosymbiont was a green alga containing a primary chloroplast (making a secondary chloroplast).

completions:
- Lepidodinium viride and its close relatives are dinophytes
- They lost their original peridinin chloroplast
- They replaced it with a green algal derived chloroplast (prasinophyte)
- Lepidodinium is the only dinophyte with a chloroplast not from the rhodoplast lineage
- The chloroplast has two membranes and no nucleomorph
- All nucleomorph genes have been transferred to the dinophyte nucleus
- The endosymbiotic event was serial secondary endosymbiosis, not tertiary endosymbiosis (algae with a primary chloroplast)

Implications:
1. Lepidodinium and its close relatives have a unique feature in the plant world.
2. They developed their current chloroplasts through multiple stages of endosymbiosis.
3. The presence of two membranes suggests a more complex relationship between the green algal chloroplast and the dinophyte.

Chloroplast
Although all chloroplasts have the same basic structure, it is now clear that there are important differences between chloroplasts of organisms from different groups. In particular, the number of plastidal genomes varies greatly (Table 3), and the proportions of plastidally encoded proteins also vary. The more distantly related the organisms, the more dissimilar are the chloroplasts. This pattern suggests that the number of genes lost from the chloroplast genome varies between lineages. In general, the greater the organismal evolutionary distance from cyanobacteria, the smaller the number of chloroplast genes. For instance, a number of red algal chloroplast genes have been transferred to the telomeric nuclear chromosomes and it has been suggested that the lack of a significant osmotic pressure against the red algal protoplast (in water) allows this chromosome loss. However, the detailed list of genes retained in different clades (Table 3) indicates a much more complex history. Clearly, we do not yet have enough information to understand the process of chloroplast gene transfer in eukaryotes. In particular, we need to know which genes are actually being transferred to the nucleus (Figure 3). Answer in complete sentences.

2. There's a notable difference in the number of genes present in the chloroplast genomes of different organisms.
3. Distinct relationships between organisms and their groups influence how many chloroplast genes they possess.
4. The number of chloroplast genes reduces with the greater evolutionary distance from cyanobacteria.
5. The loss of chloroplast genes may be a result of selective pressure.
6. An instance of this gene loss is evident in red algal chloroplast genes being transferred to the telomeric nuclear chromosomes.
7. The lack of significant osmotic pressure against the red algal protoplast allows this gene transfer.
8. However, the detailed list of retained chloroplast genes suggests a more complex history than just a simple reduction of genes.
9. We don't yet have sufficient knowledge about the processes involved in chloroplast gene transfer in eukaryotes.
10. The missing detail we need is exactly which genes are being transferred from the chloroplast to the nucleus.

Chloroplast

title: Private school
context: In Ireland, private schools (Irish: scoil phríobháideach) are unusual because a certain number of teacher's salaries are paid by the State. If the school wishes to employ extra teachers they are paid for with school fees, which tend to be relatively low in Ireland compared to the rest of the world. There is, however, a limited element of state assessment of private schools, because of the requirement that the state ensure that children receive a certain minimum education; Irish private schools must still work towards the Junior Certificate and the Leaving Certificate, for example. Many private schools in Ireland also double as boarding schools. The average fee is around €5,000 annually for most schools, but some of these schools also provide boarding and the fees may then rise up to €25,000 per year. The fee-paying schools are usually run by a religious order, i.e., the Society of Jesus or Congregation of Christian Brothers, etc.

Passage:
Thomas Owens argued, "Atheism is a self-refuting worldview because it rejects the theistic worldview while at the same time asserting that atheistic beliefs are rationally known to be true." The atheist worldview requires one to assume the validity of the scientific method to establish its worldview. When used in this context, however, the scientific method becomes circular reasoning. Therefore, the atheist worldview ends up asserting that "the scientific method" is true by presupposing its validity rather than demonstrating it.
Owens added that "the scientific method" can never be proven by the scientific method, nor can it be proven by any other method. The scientific method is simply assumed to be valid. The scientific method is an assumption of the Christian worldview, which is rationally defensible, not the atheist worldview which is inherently self-refuting. Therefore, the atheist worldview is self-refuting, self-referentially incoherent, and therefore false.

Thought Process:
1. Thomas Owens argues that atheism is a self-refuting worldview because it rejects the theistic worldview but also asserts that atheistic beliefs are rationally known to be true.
2. The atheist worldview relies on the scientific method to establish its beliefs.
3. However, when used in the context of the atheist worldview, the scientific method becomes circular reasoning.
4. The atheist worldview ends up asserting that the scientific method is true by presupposing its validity rather than demonstrating it.
5. The scientific method can never be proven by the scientific method or any other method, as it is simply assumed to be valid.
6. The scientific method is assumed to be valid in the Christian worldview, which is rationally defensible, not the atheist worldview, which is inherently self-refuting.
7. Therefore, the atheist worldview is self-refuting, self-referentially incoherent, and therefore false.

Implications:
1. The atheist worldview's reliance on the scientific method to establish beliefs leads to circular reasoning and self-refutation.
2. The scientific method is assumed to be valid in the Christian worldview, which is rationally defensible, while the atheist worldview is not self-referentially coherent.
3. The argument presented by Thomas Owens challenges the validity of the atheist worldview and suggests that it is inherently self-refuting.
4. This implies that the Christian worldview may be rationally more defensible and not subject to the same self-referential problems as the atheist worldview.
5. Recognizing the implications of this argument could lead to a better understanding of the philosophical and theological distinctions between different worldviews and how they interact.

They made two EVAs totaling 7 hours and 45 minutes. On one, they walked to the Surveyor, photographed it, and removed some parts which they returned to Earth.

title: Rhine
context: Since ~3000 yr BP (= years Before Present), human impact is seen in the delta. As a result of increasing land clearance (Bronze Age agriculture), in the upland areas (central Germany), the sediment load of the Rhine has strongly increased and delta growth has sped up. This caused increased flooding and sedimentation, ending peat formation in the delta. The shifting of river channels to new locations, on the floodplain (termed avulsion), was the main process distributing sediment across the subrecent delta. Over the past 6000 years, approximately 80 avulsions have occurred. Direct human impact in the delta started with peat mining, for salt and fuel, from Roman times onward. This was followed by embankment, of the major distributaries and damming of minor distributaries, which took place in the 11–13th century AD. Thereafter, canals were dug, bends were short cut and groynes were built, to prevent the river's channels from migrating or silting up.

title: Doctor Who
context: All the incidental music for the 2005 revived series has been composed by Murray Gold and Ben Foster and has been performed by the BBC National Orchestra of Wales from the 2005 Christmas episode "The Christmas Invasion" onwards. A concert featuring the orchestra performing music from the first two series took place on 19 November 2006 to raise money for Children in Need. David Tennant hosted the event, introducing the different sections of the concert. Murray Gold and Russell T Davies answered questions during the interval and Daleks and Cybermen appeared whilst music from their stories was played. The concert aired on BBCi on Christmas Day 2006. A Doctor Who Prom was celebrated on 27 July 2008 in the Royal Albert Hall as part of the annual BBC Proms. The BBC Philharmonic and the London Philharmonic Choir performed Murray Gold's compositions for the series, conducted by Ben Foster, as well as a selection of classics based on the theme of space and time. The event was presented by Freema Agyeman and guest-presented by various other stars of the show with numerous monsters participating in the proceedings. It also featured the specially filmed mini-episode "Music of the Spheres", written by Russell T Davies and starring David Tennant.

Graves and Winton have offered to pay the wages of any employee of the bank laid off by the Chase bank that bought Winton's bank, the First Commerce Bank and Trust Co. Winton himself is asking to be left alone to repurchase his bank in 1973, which he plans to do using funds supplied by Graves. He justifies his decision to keep the bank together by noting that in communities where banks have been closed, especially if there is no branch of another bank or other financial institution, the result is the hardship of people unable to meet their banking needs.
According to Winton, after he sold the bank to Chase in 1969, the management of the Bank of Chase First Commerce quickly removed most of the customers' money; under the regulations that were then in effect for changing bank names, a bank was not required to give every customer exactly one day's notice before changing the name. Customers without ATMs (then virtually unheard of) were thus unable to get their money out without immediate effort and expense.
A front page article in the Hamilton Journal News for April 28, 1970 by reporter Michael J. McGann stated that the First Commerce Bank "was allegedly unable to make money and the Chase bank was happy to get it." This image of First Commerce as a money-losing institution contrasted with reports in newspapers across the country that it actually made large profits despite losses in small retail business lending. An article in the Chicago Tribune from October 27, 1971, for example, carried the headline: "Business Lending Touted As Bank's Big Growth Story." During its five years under Chase ownership, First Commerce's profits may have increased to almost $5,000,000 as a whole.

Thought Process:
1. Graves and Winton offer to pay wages of employees laid off by the Chase bank.
2. Winton wants to repurchase his bank in 1973 with funds provided by Graves.
3. Winton justifies keeping the bank together because it caused hardship for people without branch access in communities where it was closed.
4. Winton sold the bank to Chase in 1969, but management removed customers' money without giving much notice.
5. A front page article in the Hamilton Journal News stated that First Commerce Bank was allegedly unable to make money and that Chase was happy to get it. This contradicts reports that the bank made large profits despite losses in small retail business lending.

Implications:
1. The relationship between Graves, Winton, and Chase was complicated, as they were involved in negotiating terms for the sale and purchase of the bank.
2. Winton's decision to keep the bank together was likely influenced by a desire to provide better access to financial services in his community.
3. The management of the Bank of Chase First Commerce appeared to be disorganized and unprofessional in handling customer funds.
4. The front page article in the Hamilton Journal News may have negatively impacted Winton's reputation as a businessman and owner of a successful bank.
5. Winton's bank was able to make significant profits during its five years under Chase ownership, despite losses in small retail business lending.

Although building construction projects typically include various common elements, such as design, financial, estimating and legal considerations, many projects of varying sizes reach undesirable end results, such as structural collapse, cost overruns, and/or litigation. Building construction is the process of adding structure to real property or construction of buildings. A real property is typically constructed over a piece of land for a specific purpose, be it for accommodation, commercial space, industrial space or any other use. An interesting aspect of building construction is that a significant amount of building construction jobs are small renovations, such as addition of a room, or renovation of a bathroom. This implies that there is an immense demand for construction of real property and the world needs more houses and buildings to accommodate its ever-growing population.

Often, the owner of the property acts as laborer, paymaster, and design team for the entire project. This implies that in many cases building construction is done on a small scale by the owners of the land, for whom it would be difficult to engage experienced professionals.

Although building construction projects typically include various common elements, such as design, financial, estimating and legal considerations, many projects of varying sizes reach undesirable end results, such as structural collapse, cost overruns, and/or litigation. This implies that although the major elements that are considered are proper design, accurate financial management, provision for legal considerations, most construction companies, particularly those that have undertaken projects at a small scale, often do not take the required care and diligence that are mandatory for a good building.

For this reason, those with experience in the field make detailed plans and maintain careful oversight during the project to ensure a positive outcome. This implies that only those with experience can manage their projects well, and without experience, it would be difficult to ensure that a positive outcome is achieved at the end of the project. Implications:

1. Building construction is a growing industry due to the world's population increase.
2. Many building construction jobs are small-scale renovations, indicating high demand for constructing real property.
3. In many cases, landowners undertake small construction projects themselves, acting as laborers, paymasters, and design teams.
4. Despite common elements like design, financial management, and legal considerations, many construction projects face undesirable outcomes, such as structural collapses, cost overruns, or legal issues.
5. Experienced professionals often create detailed plans and maintain careful oversight to ensure a positive project outcome.
6. Lack of experience may hinder a successful project outcome in construction companies, emphasizing the importance of expertise in the field.
7. Small-scale landowners may face challenges in managing construction projects without proper experience or expertise.
